ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Skelly is excellent all around. Thank you.

Most of these questions do not seem very applicable to Doctoral Seminar, as it is not really a course about concepts, butmore a course to get doctoral students started on their research. I think its very valuable to have such a course, both (a) to help doctoral students started on thinking about their research ideas, and (b) to have a way for the incoming doctoral class to get to know one another and be familiar with eachother's research ideas.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This course provided a great opportunity to adjust to the doctoral program and develop a relationship with my cohort. It provided a helpful space to develop ideas, receive helpful feedback, and voice insecurities.
Getting to know fellow doctoral students and hearing one-on-one from guest speakers.

1) Receiving very helpful feedback on fellowship proposals from a group of students with very diverse academic backgrounds.2) Seeing and other reviewing other fellowship proposals - helpful to see what others were working on; also, critiquing others' proposals helped me to improve my own3) Meeting with diverse FES seminar speakers, hearing about varied career paths and options for after graduation
It was nice to speak with seminar presenters after their seminars. The most useful aspect of the course was the "life experiences" presenters shared with us.
Having a forum to discuss entering issues that doctoral students have.
The class is low key, and the project is both do-able and super useful.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The open and flexible nature of the main deliverable for the class was helpful in that every student starts the program in a different place and with different goals. However, it seemed that the workload was uneven between students. Those who chose to submit proposals (while this was only to our benefit) were help to much higher deliverable standards than those who completed lit reviews, etc.Furthermore, while the format of providing feedback on proposal drafts is very helpful, some written response to capture individual thoughts would be helpful-- this would encourage all the students to actually read the drafts and lead to much more helpful feedback.

I think that the very nature of this course makes it a "light work load," and this is not necessarily a negative thing, considering many of the students in the course are taking other very demanding courses. However, there could be an additional component added, other than fellowship reviews and talking with seminar speakers, that could add some more continuity to each class. For example, Prof. Skelly mentioned each student presenting one environmental paper that they thought was of particular importance - this could be a good idea to follow up in future years.Also, while fellowship proposal reviews were helpful, it would have been nice for all students to have to submit written comments for each fellowship proposal submitted. During classes, often only a few students spoke up and provided comments - these were either the most vocal students, or the only students thathad actually reviewed the proposals. It would be great if all students gave both verbal and written feedback on all proposals.

The assignment (writing a fellowship app, lit review, etc.) is supremely useful to organize your thoughts about your research ideas. But, the course devoted a LOT of time to discussing fellowship applications even though only half of the class wrote fellowship applications. It would be interesting to hear more regularly from the other half of the class about their projects as well.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
I think part of the deal with presenting at the lunchtime seminar should be that presenters are required to stay at the doc seminar afterward.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: As mentioned above, this course was an excellent kick-starter for the doctoral program at F&ES.

This course set me on the path to begin thinking about big research questions I'll be exploring for my Prospectus. It also set me on the path to complete a couple of strong fellowship applications - which, apart from their use in and of themselves - were helpful to start articulating research questions.
It was helpful to understand where everyone is coming from.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It was a required course.
Required...
Mandatory for all doctoral students.
requirement (but I would have anyway)
It is required. But, I would take it anyway. It is low key, and you get to ask the noon-seminar speakers anything!

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: They actually surpassed my expectations.
Yes!
Yes

Yes - I think this course was a good means for new doctoral students to get their feet on the ground. As a PhD degree is a research degree, I think it is a great idea for students to start thinking about research ideas right off the bat, as well as to start hearing other student's research ideas. While this course didn't necessarily equip students with "new skills" or "new knowledge," it was a useful way to start turning vague research ideas into more concrete plans.
Yes.
yes.

It would be really useful for this course to continue into the second semester of the first year of the PhD program. As a first-year PhD student, there can be overload of info about the program, school, classes, etc. It would be great to be able to re-connect in the second semester once everyone has a better perspective of what they want to be doing and know what resources they are seeking.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages were getting to know fellow doc students.
N/A
Helpful comments on fellowship applications

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You really should do a formal research/fellowship proposal in order to get the most out of this class.

This course is mandatory, so this question is not directly applicable. However, I would say to new doctoral students that the course is something to look forward to - a way to learn about many different trajectories a PhD student can take (from meeting and speaking with all the FES Seminar speakers), as well as a way to start shaping your research ideas and a forum by which to bounce your ideas off your peers.
Take advantage of your fellow students.
Participate in discussions.
